idioms.sense: the things that are discussed at the end of an official meeting that do not appear on the agenda
examples: I think we've finished item four. Now is there any other business?

idioms.sense: to be very good
to have everything that you need in order to be able to start something immediately
examples: All we need is a car and we'll be in business.

idioms.text: be in the business of doing something
idioms.sense: to regard a particular activity as an essential part of what you do
examples: Restaurant owners everywhere are in the business of building relationships.

idioms.sense: a way of saying that things will continue as normal despite a difficult situation
examples: It's business as usual at the factory, even while investigators sift through the bomb wreckage.

idioms.sense: a way of saying that financial and commercial matters are the important things to consider and you should not be influenced by friendship, etc.
to start dealing with the matter that needs to be dealt with, or doing the work that needs to be done
examples: Let’s get down to business right away—we’ll stop for coffee later.
OK, let's get down to business.

idioms.sense: to do the things that you normally do
examples: streets filled with people going about their daily business
market traders going about their daily business

idioms.text: have no business doing something | have no business to do something
idioms.sense: to have no right to do something
examples: You have no business being here.

idioms.sense: very much, very fast, very well, etc.
examples: I've been working like nobody's business to get it finished in time.

idioms.sense: to be serious in your intentions
examples: He has the look of a man who means business.
He says he's going to make changes, and I think he means business.

idioms.sense: to think about your own affairs and not ask questions about or try to get involved in other people’s lives
examples: ‘What are you reading?’ ‘Mind your own business!’
I was just sitting there, minding my own business, when a man started shouting at me.

idioms.text: not be in the business of doing something
idioms.sense: not to be intending to do something (which it would be surprising for you to do)
examples: I'm not in the business of getting other people to do my work for me.

idioms.sense: having stopped operating as a business because there is no more money or work available
examples: The new regulations will put many small businesses out of business.
Some travel companies will probably go out of business this summer.
The company went out of business during the recession.

idioms.sense: to look for customers, passengers, etc. in order to do business
examples: taxis plying for hire outside the theatre

senses.text: to stop and hold a moving object or person, especially in your hands
examples: She managed to catch the keys as they fell.

The dog caught the stick in its mouth.
I threw the bag in the air and she caught it.
‘Throw me over that towel, will you?’ ‘OK. Catch!’

He caught her up in his arms.

to catch a bus/train/flight

catch something It is unusual to catch measles more than once.
catch something from somebody I think I must have caught this cold from you.

She caught sight of a car in the distance.

catch somebody doing something I caught her smoking in the bathroom.

catch yourself doing something She caught herself wondering whether she had made a mistake.
catch somebody + adv./prep. He was caught with bomb-making equipment in his home.
Mark walked in and caught them at it (= in the act of doing something wrong).
thieves caught in the act

I caught him just as he was leaving the building.
I was hoping to catch you at home (= to see you at home when you were there).

(British English) to catch the post (= post letters before the box is emptied)
(British English, informal) Bye for now! I'll catch you later (= speak to you again later).

She caught sight of a car in the distance.

catch (in/on something) Her dress caught on a nail.
catch something (in/on something) He caught his thumb in the door.
catch somebody/something + adv./prep. The stone caught him on the side of the head.
catch somebody a blow + adv./prep. She caught him a blow on the chin.

These logs are wet: they won't catch.

idioms.sense: to be involved in an argument or fight between two other people or groups
examples: When they quarrel, I am often caught in the middle.

idioms.text: be caught short (British English also be taken short)
idioms.sense: to suddenly feel a strong need to go to the toiletto be put at a disadvantage
to be in a difficult situation when any action you take will have bad results

idioms.text: (caught/stuck) between a rock and a hard place
idioms.sense: in a situation where you have to choose between two things, both of which are unpleasant
to stop breathing for a moment because of fear, shock, etc.to start to be able to breathe normally again after running or doing exercise that makes you tired
examples: When he said he had resigned, I caught my breath in surprise.

idioms.sense: to become ill with a coldto have problems
examples: The film caught a cold over the outstanding debt.

idioms.sense: to catch a very bad cold
to attract somebody’s attention
examples: Can you catch the waiter's eye?

idioms.sense: to attract or please somebody
examples: She looked through the hotel advertisements until one of them caught her fancy.

idioms.text: catch it (British English) (North American English catch hell, get it)
idioms.sense: to be punished or spoken to angrily about something
examples: If your dad finds out you'll really catch it!

idioms.sense: to get an advantage over somebody by doing something when they are not expecting it and not ready for it
to surprise somebody by doing something when they are not expecting it and not ready for it
to upset somebody by reminding them of something they are particularly sensitive about
to catch somebody in the act of doing something wrong or committing a crime

idioms.text: catch somebody with their pants down (British English also catch somebody with their trousers down)
idioms.sense: to arrive or do something when somebody is not expecting it and not ready, especially when they are in an embarrassing situation

idioms.text: the early bird catches the worm
idioms.sense: the person who takes the opportunity to do something before other people will have an advantage over them
to make somebody unsteady and in danger of fallingto make somebody surprised and no longer calm
examples: I was thrown off balance by the sudden gust of wind.
The sudden movement threw him off balance.
The senator was clearly caught off balance by the unexpected question.

idioms.sense: (to put somebody) at a disadvantage or in difficulty
examples: Advances in drone technology have caught lawmakers on the back foot.
The side that’s on the back foot, struggling to defend, will usually give away more penalties.
We'd like to put the fossil fuel industry on the back foot.
